text: Gazella borbonica, commonly known as the Bourbon gazelle or European gazelle, is an extinct gazelle which existed in Europe during the Pleistocene epoch. It was described by Charles Depéret in 1884. It had rather long, moderately divergent and slightly recurved horns and was about the same size as the modern Dorcas Gazelle, with a shoulder height of about 60 cm. Remains have been found in France, the Netherlands and south-east England. Taxonomic synonyms include Gazella anglica Newton, 1884 and Gazella daviesii Hinton, 1906 BioLib. == References == Category:Mammals described in 1884 Category:Gazella Category:Fossil taxa described in 1884 Category:Pleistocene even-toed ungulates Category:Pleistocene mammals of Europe Category:Prehistoric bovids
title: Gazella borbonica
